text: <@U01CN6HP5J6> has joined the channel

how can a strategy know if `place_order` successfully met all validation checks please? currently this returns `None`
```def place_order(self, market: Market, order) -> None:
    runner_context = self.get_runner_context(*order.lookup)
    if self.validate_order(runner_context, order):
        runner_context.place()
        market.place_order(order)```
want to put some additional logic to handle order placement validation failures, please let me know how best to handle. thanks

None
want to put some additional logic to handle order placement validation failures, please let me know how best to handle. thanks

text:
When backtesting with flumine, the `market_book` and `live_market` are received on each update by `process_market_book`.

In that data, how can I tell whether or not:

• the market will go inplay? This is different to the `inplay` flag that defines whether or not it is actually inplay.
• whether or not it the bsp is available?

text: Hi, I'm a beginner with betfair but familar with tick trading data. I'am trying to create essentially a time and sales file using the Pro historical data. But when I merge the order book data and the time and sales file I generate, the results look a little strange. Generally, you can see the exact traded size removed from the order book. But occasionaly, there seems to be a trade that was adjusted later on (size doesn't match order book) and occasionally I see exactly half of the reported trade size being removed from the book. To calculate the trades I just take the difference from the current trd cache and the newest trd cache. What is the correct way to calculate the amount that was traded? And am I overlooking something in my calculation?

elements.text: Hi, I'm a beginner with betfair but familar with tick trading data. I'am trying to create essentially a time and sales file using the Pro historical data. But when I merge the order book data and the time and sales file I generate, the results look a little strange. Generally, you can see the exact traded size removed from the order book. But occasionaly, there seems to be a trade that was adjusted later on (size doesn't match order book) and occasionally I see exactly half of the reported trade size being removed from the book. To calculate the trades I just take the difference from the current trd cache and the newest trd cache. What is the correct way to calculate the amount that was traded? And am I overlooking something in my calculation?

text: If I'm reading correctly, could it not just be that the rest of the order was cancelled? i.e. order was for £10, £5 trades, so traded volume increases by £5, but the remainder is cancelled so the order book reduces by £10 overall

elements.text: If I'm reading correctly, could it not just be that the rest of the order was cancelled? i.e. order was for £10, £5 trades, so traded volume increases by £5, but the remainder is cancelled so the order book reduces by £10 overall

text: £5 matched is £10 traded, so divide by 2

elements.text: £5 matched is £10 traded, so divide by 2

text: To give an example, the current top atl was 34.96 @ 1.39. I get a trd update indicating that 3.7 traded @  1.39. The next atl update indicates the size is now 31.26 @ 1.39.  This makes sense to me. But then sometimes the indicated traded quantity is double what I expect.

text: Chance the amount available was added/remove in the same cycle + currency fluctuations

elements.text: Chance the amount available was added/remove in the same cycle + currency fluctuations

text: Basically, whenever I see the order book change by the exact amount that was traded, I should be multiplying the trd amount by 2. And sorry what do you mean by the amount available was added/removed in the same cycle?

elements.text: Basically, whenever I see the order book change by the exact amount that was traded, I should be multiplying the trd amount by 2. And sorry what do you mean by the amount available was added/removed in the same cycle?

text:
If there is £20 sitting at 2.00 and someone places a £10 bet at 2.00 that will result in amount available dropping to £10 and the amount traded increasing by £20, you shouldn't be doing any multiplying,

Now it is entirely possible that at exactly the same time (same cycle) someone adds or cancels to that amount at 2.00.

elements.text:
If there is £20 sitting at 2.00 and someone places a £10 bet at 2.00 that will result in amount available dropping to £10 and the amount traded increasing by £20, you shouldn't be doing any multiplying,

Now it is entirely possible that at exactly the same time (same cycle) someone adds or cancels to that amount at 2.00.

text:
Here's the example I was talking about (ommitted the other selection id: 47973). This is the first trade of the day for selection id 47972:
```{"op":"mcm","clk":"1347522886","pt":1588287791350,"mc":[{"id":"1.170358581","rc":[{"atb":[[1.01,1231.91],[1.27,116.43],[1.02,635.82],[1.22,0]],"id":47972},{"atl":[[1.39,34.96]],"id":47972}],"con":true,"img":false}]}
{"op":"mcm","clk":"1347538093","pt":1588290021375,"mc":[{"id":"1.170358581","rc":[{"trd":[[1.39,3.7]],"ltp":1.39,"tv":3.7,"id":47972},{"atl":[[1.39,31.26]],"id":47972}],"con":true,"img":false}]}```
In the above I would have to multiply the trd quantity by 2.  But below is an example when the trd quantity is exactly 2 * the amount removed the book.
```{"op":"mcm","clk":"1347678421","pt":1588309262118,"mc":[{"id":"1.170358581","rc":[{"atb":[[1.26,295.47]],"id":47972}],"con":true,"img":false}]}
{"op":"mcm","clk":"1347692803","pt":1588310667705,"mc":[{"id":"1.170358581","rc":[{"trd":[[1.26,8.7]],"ltp":1.26,"tv":8.7,"id":47972},{"atb":[[1.26,291.12]],"id":47972}],"con":true,"img":false}]}```
So what would be the correct way to record the trades for these two updates. Currently, I have something like:
```Sz|TrdPx
3.7|1.39
8.7|1.26```
But should the size 3.7 really be 7.4? Or should the size 8.7 really be 4.35?
